Name: Feynman's Tips on Physics: Reflections, Advice, Insights, Practice - A Problem-Solving Supplement to the Feynman Lectures on Physics

ReviewList.Text: I purchased this, thinking I needed it when purchasing the lectures, but it was already included in that purchase.
It is not only a good suplement to the Feynman's Lessons, but also an independent book of iteresting exercises and a shows a excellent point of view on how to face the study of Physics

Feynman does it again, his expanse intelligence and foresight is captured very well in this book. As an undergraduate physics major I can say that all the tips I picked up in this book were on the money and extremely helpful.

Firstly, ANYTHING by Richard Feynman is compulsive reading.  Having said that I was a little bit disappointed because I was expecting some personal tips on his math techniqes.  There is an interesting approach to differentiation and some stuff on numerical integration.  There is a great deal on gyroscopes. There is a common sense homily to those who have to face the fact that SOMEONE has to be in the lower quartile of a class, and not to get disturbed by this statistical fact.  For the few dollars it costs it is well worth it !

Of course all of Feynman's writing is very interesting, but something special about this book are the chapters on applied physics, like how you make a real gyroscope for ship or plane navigation.  If you're more interested in engineering than math these chapters are really engrossing.  And they're also tangible -- real life examples of how things were actually built.

Fantastic. Feynman is a fantastic teacher - this is tips on Physics. But there is also a bit of life coaching. So, for anybody struggling with any academic subject the introduction is the must read. He's speaking to the hard worker moving into the place in life when the room is filled with hard workers and not many "atta boys" (or girls).
Don't overlook the interviews, they give deep insight into the man, his depth and his genius. It's very unfortunate he never got to his, "guide for the perplexed".
This is a great book to go along with the three Feynman lecture books. It has some great tips but prior physics' knowledge is assumed.

Unless you're a physicist there are parts of this that will be beyond you, s they were beyond me.  Even so, a little commitment can teach you a lot.  But if you're a teacher, this is a gem, physics aside.  Feynman has important things to say about student motivation and moral, and about liberating students in their own terms without sacrificing content.  These tips travel far beyond the boundaries of physics into just about anything we might teach.

The years leading up to January 1, 1000 were tumultuous ones. Some seers of the time saw evil tidings in Y1K, as it was known then, while other gurus spun the date for its concinnity, and deemed it propitious. In the end, despite all the hype and hoopla, and except for the publication of a book by a scientist from the future, it turned out to be "just another day".
He states the basics in language that is understandable to most people who are new to the science.  I liked it.

This book is a reconstruction of lectures given by Feynman at the end of the second semester of Feynman's freshman physics course designed specifically to assist students who felt like they were not going to be able to pass the course.  This book should be required reading for every first-year physics and engineering student!

Feynman looks at problem solving from the view of the struggling student, and his techniques show not only his skill, but his empathy.  Feynman not only solves the problems, but shows his roadmaps and strategies for wading through the swamp and coming through to the dry ground success at the end.

all books by feynmann are both fun to read and very informative,  he lets you know when a difficult topic is difficult - some authors write in such a way that even the difficult material is easy.  feynmann tells it like it is.  This goes for all of his  books
feynman always has a unique way of looking at things which is worth paying attention to regardless of your level of sophistication
This book is not must read. If you are a physics major that knows calculus you do not really need to read this at all.
I found this book extremely useful and enjoyable to read. I suggest reading this book before starting to read Feynman Lectures.
I thought this book was incredibly insightful period.
Well  written. Typically Feynman.
Dr. Feynman is a great read.
great book even for dummies
I was there and heard these things in the early 60's.  the lectures are still just as fascinating now as they were then, although I have forgotten most or all of the math that went with them.
I really enjoyed these books but I'm  geting tired of having to write reviews om them. It should be enough to rate them!
